Some correction:
 
On battery - iP8+ can't focus properly sometimes *but mostly on lowlight scenes*.

For someone who wants to buy this phone, you can buy this phone for:
 
1. Camera - One of the best camera you'll ever seen, I do have S7 along with iPhone 8 Plus, S7 edge do better at some particular things, have sharper and less noise than iPhone 8 Plus. Even at lowlight, S7 do little bit better, iP8+ can't focus properly sometimes. Honest opinion!
 
2. Display - Also, S7 has better display than iP8+, more visible under sunlight, more sharper and more vivid!
 
3. Features - microSD card, headphone jack, wireless charging. Yes, iP8+ also wireless charging but it doesn't have fast charging. Not to forget, heart rate sensor!
 
But don't buy for this purpose (I'm not hardly prevent but not recommended):
 
1. Battery - This phone now 2 years old so battery may get degraded. It's not bad battery but recommended to carry along with powerbank. 
You will get decent battery if not worse.
 
2. Performance - You might asked this "Performance? Snapdragon 820/Exynos 8890 is not good chipsets?" To make this clear, I don't criticize the chipsets, it is about Samsung optimization. I'm pretty agree and gonna admit that Samsung UI is little bit laggy, but just not recommended for gaming person. It handled your daily tasks very good, but if you are gaming/heavy user type, advisable to lower your display resolution to Full HD, it won't stressed much out your chipset to push hard more power.

Download from playstore or enable from settings. The files and apps you install on secure folder are completely isolated from your other stuff. It's like a phone inside a phone. You can install two copies of all apps more like dual apps but very secure. It's password or fingerprint protected and if anyone try to tamper more than instructed no then only can be unlocked from Samsung knox Website. It can't be force closed or uninstalled from settings. Biggest plus when you don't need secure apps just turn off secure folder it won't even send notification. Just YouTube it for more details.

Overview of the galaxy S7 after 3 months...
 
Bought the phone in September during Flipkart sale over the oneplus 3 and seriously its the biggest sin that I've done... 
 
Build quality, 
Its good but, the oneplus 3 was much sleek and light... Also the argonomics on the oneplus 3 were much better... And personally, I find 5.5 inches screen as good...
 
Screen, 
Screen is good, very crisp and very easily visible even under direct sunlight... Just outstanding
 
Battery and charging, 
This is where the biggest disappointment is... The battery was good when I bought the phone, but as it has aged, the battery life is decreasing... Infact, whenever the screen is at 2k, it sips battery like crazy... I have to charge the device almost 2-3 times if I use it very extensively... Also when kept on 2k, the device tends to heat a bit and that too with moderate usage... Things improve with 1080p but what's the use if you cannot really use the device's maximum potential... 
 
Charging speeds are a bit slow, coming from a dash charging enabled device it feels very slow... But its okayish, also it charges very fast after 70%, fast as compared to others...
 
Software and UI experience, 
I'm kind of disappointed with this, I used to have a galaxy note 3 years back and at that time the features it provided were great amd provided by none in the market, the features are same and almost nothing new is added... That disappoints me a bit, because I expected more... Also the UI isn't mature enough, the oneplus 3 had a lot of customisations, the S7 being a samsung flagship isn't that great... 
 
One small thing I love about this device is, that if you have a password set, so without unlocking the phone, you cannot toggle the mobile data, wifi or the location on/off... Even you cannot switch the device off... Only you can restart the phone... So that's a good safety measure by samsung because you can always track your phone...
 
Camera 
The camera is good, it captures great images, low light photography is also good but now as everyone is heading towards the dual camera and the portrait mode thing, the camera feels outdated... Strangely the video I used to shoot with the oneplus 3 at 1080p 60fps felt a lot smoother than the one with this device... But one thing about samsung devices is that, the front camera is exceptionally wide angle and it makes selfies more easy as you don't have to strech your hand much... 
 
Speaker, earpiece sound quality etc, 
The speaker is okay but is tinny and lacks bass, adequately loud... Could be better, but can be considered as this device has waterproofing... 
 
Earpiece is very loud and clear and during the calls, the minimum volume of the speaker and the maximum volume of the earpiece almost match...
 
But the sound quality from the audio jack is very low, even at maximum volume the sound doesn't feel loud, even in silence I had to keep the volume upto more than 70% to make it sound clearly audible... This is a very big disappointment because even budget phones have better audio quality than this...
 
Aging/issues 
As I had upgraded it from the oneplus 3, the day I bought it I felt meh... I agree that the camera quality in the night is exceptional but apart from that there's nothing great about this handset... The day light shots almost feel equal if compared with the op3... And one thing I noticed is that, I had the oneplus 3 for almost 10 months and even after 10 months it used to feel very snappy... Whatever I threw at it, it handled it with ease... But I don't feel the same with the S7, and I've just used the phone for 3 months... 
 
Talking about the issues, my gallery app isn't showing me old photos, whenever I click on the old photos, it just stops responding, same happens sometimes even with chrome and Instagram, I had tried cleaning the cache but that doesn't help either... I never had these type of issues with my op3... But both of my samsung phones, the note 3 and the grand 2 had similar type of issues... 
 
The auto brightness sensor also doesn't feel well callibrated... The brightness is sometimes more and some less than what it should be... It doesn't detect the ambient light that well... And one thing I noticed, that if you have a light source right behind you it cranks up the brightness and you just can't lower it... If you try adjusting it, it just cranks up again with my op3 if I set the brightness manually, then it would remain at the same brightness until I manually toggle the brightness on/off... And that was good...
 
Something I love in this device is the vibration.motor, it is so finely tuned that I have toggled everything on that needs vibration... I enjoy it... 
 
Final word, 
As 2018 is on the way and there will be a hell lot of new smartphones launching in 2018, I would strongly suggest not to buy this smartphone at this time... Because the oreo update will be the last one to hit this device and that too in late February or early march... And after that, there will be nothing special left in this device... It doesn't have a dual camera, so no potrait mode and now as we are watching even the budget segment with potrait mode that will be a major hit if you buy this...
 
Also the samsung UI, I don't know how the Samsung experience is, but it feels similar to touchwiz, so I would strongly recommend to stay away from phones running touchwiz, because the UI isn't worth your hard earned money... Yes, it does have a bunch of sensors like the heart rate etc, but in a busy life you will hardly care about them.being present... 
 
Samsung will really spoil their game if they won't work on their UI... Considering how their devices age and the plenty of bugs we encounter once the device starts getting old, makes samsung devices not worth...

I don't have the S8 so I can't say for sure.  I got a Samsung Galaxy On8 (3GB of RAM) which is also running the Samsung Experience UI 8.1 on top of Android 7.0 Nougat. It does consume more RAM, I get around 1 GB free without any third party apps running in the background.  But it doesn't lag at all on User Interface. The UI transition animations are slow however to give user the perception of smoothness throughout the UI. UI transition animations are slow on all Samsung phones by default so you maybe perceiving slow UI transition animations as lag. More free RAM isn't necessarily better, what matters is better RAM management which keeps apps in RAM so they don't restart. You can disable those system applications which you aren't gonna use like Flipboard app and Microsoft suite of applications. You can also make the UI transition animations fast. Turn on developer mode by going to Settings > About Phone > Software Info > Keep tapping on Build Number until you see developer mode is enabled. Now in Settings > Developer Mode > Set window animation scale, transition animation scale and animator duration scale all to 0.5x. There you go.

Faster than I've seen on any phone or point and shoot cameras. Dual Pixel works like a charm in any lighting condition.  Samsung's camera computational algorithms works intelligently, like determining the best image values in different lighting conditions. What I really like is the pro mode, it's not just easy to use but really well thought out. I'm very much into smartphone photography, and I love taking nice shots. I have had quite a good camera phones like the Nokia N8 in the past, a great camera phone during its time. The S7 is miles ahead of N8's camera quality and there's no comparison between the two except when it comes to flash type. Xenon flash freezes action so you can take shots like this in low light.   
I've taken difficult shots like birds in flight mode with my S7, could have done better if it had optical zoom. Panaromas shots are high resolution with plenty of details (huge mb) and it's the best I've ever seen on a phone.  OIS works like really good in low light.  The S7 Camera is indeed awesome and top notch.

Just keep your phone in slanting position so that air can pass through its sides, display and back at the same time... If you keep your phone flat, it won't allow the air to flow from the back or display which may result in heating...
Even I don't have any issues with the charging yet... Those were some precautions so that your device does not overheat...

Have already disabled the fast charging but still, the charging is very fast with the bundled fast charger. Even with a 2V/1.5A charger, the charging time is pretty much the same. Not that I've a complaint regarding fast charging. It's a great feature. And it's normal to heat up during charging. The heat gradually reduces as the battery charges over certain percent. Most of the smartphones do get warm while on charge. I was looking for a way to reduce my S7 getting warm during charging. My room remains pretty cool, so tried charging with the case removed but not much effect. I guess, I've to deal with it.

I had no charging issues so far with my Samsung phones. I had used the S6 edge plus for over eight months with fast charging and never had any problems same goes for my current S7 with no issues till date. I unplug it immediately after it reaches 100℅ I don't charge my phone overnight.

I never allow my S7 to get below 40-50%... And I always turn the room's fan on while it is charging... Thirdly I don't keep the device flat, it is in slanting position, so that maximum air can pass... This way the device heats much less....
You can alternatively disable the fast charging in settings...

Those software features on S7 and S8 are amazing and years ahead of the competition.  Only, when you own a S7 or S8 can you appreciate these adanced software options. The S8 dedicated Bixby button is the future and in approx 5/6 years phones will be almost 100% voice commands only.  Plus, if you prefer google assist, then you can change/use it on the Bixby button. Huawei flagship phones also now have a dedicated assistant button.
 
The amazing near bezel less design is also the future, giving a larger screen with nearly the same size device. Plus the amazing new infinity Amoled display.  There are still some ugly branded phones available with giant bezels, but they will slowly disapear as the public wants bigger screens, but not bigger phones. Sony Xperia phones are a typical example with the same ugly design for 5 years with giant bezels and same limited display of 5 years.

The S7 has a smart manager/device maintenance feature plus various power saving and performance modes built on top of stock Android.   It optimizes itself automatically with very little to no user interference and provides options for gaining better performance or battery life. The S7 has tons of features not found on stock Android, features that stock Android will only be getting after a couple of years or probably never. That's why Samsung's last year flagship devices are ahead of the competition and can rival and even beat this year's flagships from other manufacturers. The only thing that's better than the S7 is the S8. And yet 95 percent of the new features of the S8 can be installed on the S7.  All of the APKs of S8 including the new launcher, widgets, Bixby, Always On Display layouts, and stock S8 apps are out now and can be installed on the S7. There is really no point buying an expensive 2017 flagship unless you want a larger and taller display. You can buy the S7 or S7 edge for a bargain and get 95 percent of the features of the S8.

You need to let the phone optimize itself for a week or two after updating to Nougat. I am a newcomer to flagship phones. I have the Boost variant with a 2.2 GHz Snapdragon 820 processor and 530 CPU Adreno. It has 4 GB of RAM and 32 GB of internal ROM. I opted to add a 32 GB Micro SD card. The phone overall is excellent. It is very snappy with no lag. The QHD AMOLED Display is really crisp. The Adaptive setting is what works best for my viewing. 
 
The Earpiece and Speakerphone Audio is LOUD and Clear. The supplied ear buds have a good sound, better bass sound. The 3000 Mah battery last me all day yielding me 60% remaining at the end of my day with conservation measures like keeping the GPS and Wi-Fi off when not in use. I lose about 0.80% per hour in standby. 
 
The supplied fast charger does what it was designed to do. The fingerprint sensor has worked very well for me. I have to still set up the Samsung Pay. The notifications and ringtones are loud too. 
 
The only issues I am experiencing so far is transferring data (audio) to the SD card. My photos were transferred with no problem. I must be missing a credential that is not set correctly.  Other than that, I am delighted with the device. Any help with my issue may be directed to   william.unger1967@gmail.com   please.

Absolutely Wrong.  Samsung has been using heat pipes in its laptops for 6/7 years and used  its heat pipes knowledge and experience in their smartphones. Some Samsung Ultrabook laptops had dual heat pipes.                                                                                                          
 
Samsung's own CPU, the Exynos doesn't need heat pipes, but  Qualcomm Snapdragon  Cpu's need heat pipes. Snapdragon have had  heating problems since the SD810
 
Samsung avoided using the SD810 in the S6 for this reason and so by using its own Exynos chip didn't need any heat pipes.  Sony used the SD810 and needed heat pipes to overcome these heating problems. But, Sony already had other thermal heating problems in its design  which only increased this heat to levels causing shut downs and/or permanent damage. Other brands that used SD810, usually throttled down the CPU.
 
Here is a picture breakdown of a Samsung Ultrabook with dual heat pipes from July 2012.

 
 
Modern CPU heat pipes are typically made of copper and use water as the working fluid.

I was about to buy a Sony Xperia XZ but opted for a Samsung Galaxy S7 instead because it's cheaper than the XZ which costs just as much as a S7 edge, and I'm so happy I've made the right decision. S7 is the best smartphone I've ever owned. S7 is superior in every way to the XZ - from the design, screen, camera, audio quality, battery life, to the user interface and software features. 
 
- XZ is ridiculously big and bulky for a 5.2-inch phone. It's as big as the S7 edge already with 5.5-inch display. S7 is smaller, thinner and easier to hold and, unlike the XZ which has sharp edges, S7 has rounded edges which make its more manageable and it can even be used single-handedly. 
 
- S7's screen is amazing. It's bright, has vivid colors, great contrast, deep blacks which is typical of AMOLEDs and is even perfectly legible outdoors. With the latest Nougat update, you can even set the display resolution to 1080p or 720p. XZ has oversaturated colors for an IPS LCD display, and 1080p is not flagship-grade.
 
- Touchwiz also looks nicer and more consistent than Xperia launcher. S7 also has so much more software features than XZ like Always-On Display, Private Mode, etc. I was also very happy to find out that the fast-charger is included in the box with S7. And there is even a software feature to enable and disable fast charging.
 
- S7's camera UI and hardware are jampacked with features - 4k, OIS, phase detection, slow motion video, different cool image and video modes that you can apply. Not to mention both the image and video qualities are excellent, and S7 doesn't overheat AT ALL when recording 4k video until you run out of memory. XZ's camera features and quality just pales in comparison.
 
- S7's mono speaker quality is surprisingly louder than XZ's dual speakers. The audio quality via 3.5mm jack is also loud unlike in the XZ.
 
- S7 also has great battery life. Lasts a whole day for heavy use, and can last up to 3 days for moderate use. XZ has horrible battery life.
 
S7 is a perfect all-rounder. It's a perfectly-sized phone. Not too big and not too small. It's a perfect work of engineering. And it's complete. Everyone will find everything they look for in a smartphone in S7. XZ lacks so many features both hardware and software. Even the accessories that come with XZ in the box are not complete. And it is unjustifiably overpriced. It is selling for around 50 dollars more than S7 edge here.
Fantastic phone. Runs flawlessly. There is no better phone..well not till S8 comes.

I've has the same issues with the S1, S2, and S3, all touch screen issues. Went to HTC and never had a problem. Got the S7 only due to the fact that the M10 was a Bell only phone, I had no choice.  For a $800-$900 phone, its crap. My M7 still works better. Should have gotten the G5.

Otherwise, the phone is really solid and fortunately has a microSD slot for extra storage again.

About Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge 
1) I have to reboot the phone a couple times a day, because it sometimes fails to "wake up", especially after a recharge. Reboots are wasting valuable time. 
2) The major issue I have is that data, in particular photos, get corrupted at a rate of 1 file per day. This can be avoided by backing up your data on a daily basis! Bottom line: data on the microSD card within the Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge is not safe! I can hear a Samsung spokesperson pointing at an incompatible app. Errors such as 0x80071AC3, occur during copying, and that has never occurred on my previous phones. Corrupted data prevents you from copying your photo folders. Once a corrupted file is encountered, file copying stops, and you have to figure out where that corrupted file is located. Deleting corrupt files on the microSD card has not always worked. Running the DiskCheck application didn't fix the problem either. The only option left is formatting.  
3) While playing games, the Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge either slows down considerably, or stops working altogether. Very irritating!

Been using this since March '16. Preordered it and it was bundled with the Gear VR. Nice phone, but the blue earpiece already had a like a millimeter of paint chipped off. It's hardly noticeable so no big deal. Also, the transparent plastic cover of the flash and heart rate monitor seems to be easily scratched. I had to use some toothpaste and tissue paper to remove those scratches.
 
I suggest you buy one of those spigen slim or rugged armor cases to protect your phone. Get their steinheil curved screen protectors too. Get a high-speed and capacity SD card and you got one hell of a phone.
 
Camera is one of the best. I had to shelf my Canon DSLR for this one if I'm going on a tour somewhere. Focus is really fast.
 
Battery life is so-so. Just remember to get one of those 15,000 mAh powerbanks if you're going on a long trip without any outlets available. Battery lasts at around 8 hours with the wifi/mobile data on and frequent music playing and camera use. 
 
I had a Samsung S4 and an iPhone 5s before I had this one. Games are super fast. It also really heats up when you use fast charging and cover it with a pillow, so I suggest turning off fast charging if you're gonna leave it overnight plugged in.
 
It'll also head up considerably when you use your VR headset. By the way, this is not the Note 7. People would often stereotype this phone as the one that explodes.
 
Waterproofness is an added bonus. Just becareful not to charge it after giving it a dip. Also, the speakers will be unusable for quite a while until it completely dries off.
 
Overall, it's a nice phone by itself. It ain't rugged until you dress it up.

Now it depends on whether you have a problem with using a chinese phone or not. If not, you can exclude the S7 because it has just a better camera but rest is about the same for higher price.
 
Next thing is OnePlus 3 or Mi5 or 5S. They cost about the same and are about the same. Mi5 has worse build quality and but a smaller body and you said that you want a smaller phone (of course you could go full compact with an iPhone SE or Xperia X Compact). For the most things they are the same, even the camera seems to be the same sensor. I wouldn't weigh the extra RAM of OP 3 too much because that isn't that big of a difference. And the last difference is the back which is metal on the OP 3 or Glass on the Mi5 so there your personal preference is important. If you use a custom ROM or launcher, software isn't an issue, but if not, I think OnePlus 3 is better because it also has an international firmware while the Mi5 is specially made for China so there will be some apps missing or wrong translations or a UI that is similar to iOS.
 
If you wait for the Mi5S and if it has the same price as these, there is no competition and it will be better.
 
If you want a long software support or don't like these above, you can wait for the new Google devices.
 
Because of the fact these phones you said all having android, I think you don't want an iPhone.

It's not *just* Chrome tbh but any browser that uses the Webkit/Blink with the V8 JS engine including Opera.
 
It doesn't matter which Android browser you're using because almost all of them use the same engine while others are mere Webview wrappers.
 
The stable Chrome channel on Android has no official armv8 64-bit Aarch64 build. It is still not built with any armv8 compiler optimisations in order to maintain compatibility with legacy 32-bit armv7. Firefox, the only real alternative performance is even worse and tends to crash.
 
The Samsung browser is pretty much the only browser that is compiled specifically for the Exynos Soc and this is why it performs better.

I had it for 5 months and it all started very well...but... Great photos, very useful quick access to the cam app but after 5 months the battery started to drain drastically. If I had 100 % at midnight, in the morning it would be about 70-80% without touching the phone. After not even an hour of using the phone in the sun (with auto display settings) it would drop below 50 %. All in all I ended up charging my phone 2-3 times a day without any heavy usage. A week ago I decided to go back to a "sheep phone" iPhone 6s Plus that is definitely a bit more limited in terms of accessing extra options but the battery lasts up to 2 days and the camera is at the same level if not better than Galaxy s7 (apart from low light shots). Last weekend when I sent my pics taken on iPhone to my friend who also owns Galaxy s7 - his firs comment was - you must have improved the quality of your pic with some apps....and he is a photo geek. Anyway if you want a flashy phone that you can't fully rely on (battery, os) go for s7 if you want a reliable mobile friend you know what I would recommend...The choice as always is yours!

After taking my beloved S7 on vacation and dropping it less than 3 feet into 1 inch of water the ear speaker failed completely.  I called Verizon for a replacement since it was less than 60 days old.  Water damage is not covered on water resistant phones even if they have the IP68 rating.  So basically a phone that is advertised in a commercial promoting it being dunked in water does not cover it if there is water damage.  They will allow you to send it in for repair.  Now I have to be without my new $800 S7 for up to 9 days so that it can be repaired.  Like most people, I use my phone for business and it is my only business phone.  
 
I was a loyal Samsung customer having an s3, galaxy note tablet, galaxy s2 tablet and now the s7 but after this I will not choose Samsung ever again.  I love the phone but this was just the completely wrong way to handle this issue.  I am glad to get it repaired.  Buyers should beware.

Shatterproof? I have never seen Samsung advertising the S7 as shatterproof. And it certainly is not shatterproof as it has the same Gorilla Glass 4 as most other devices. It is scratch-resistant at the most. Phones like the Droid Turbo 2 and the S7 Active, however, are advertised as shatterproof because they have plastic (plastic coated on Glass on the S7 Active) screens which prevents shattering.  
Random restart might have something to do with the software or maybe even the hardware. I haven't heard a lot of people complaining about something like this so you might be having a defective unit. 
The device is IP68 "water-resistant" and not "waterproof" and that too only upto 1.5 metres of depth for half an hour, though this should be more than enough for minor submersion in a pool or something of that sort.

Samsung Galaxy S7 - A brief review on IP68 certification.
 
The Pros - Most of the overall phone. The smudges on the screen and what not are pretty minimal things. Really really like(d) the phone overall, but....
 
The Cons - Definitely don't go about pouring champagne on it like Lil Wayne. Although it's all over websites and advertisements that it is water resistant, it still has water indicators on the phone that will void your warranty.
 
I've owned the phone for 4 days and the phone has gone into the pool once. Fun to do at first, everyone gasps, and you pull it out working fine. Which mine is in fact water resistant, however the lenses do not keep out the water like the other components. Condensation has made my camera inoperable, not in the sense that it's broken, but in the sense that every photo makes it look like it's in the water. And after going back to Samsung, they refused to replace the phone and said that I would have to pay to fix the faulty components in the defective device (because it was "water damaged." ha)
 
Long story short, just because it's water resistant, doesn't mean you should have it anywhere around water. And if you need a waterproof case on a water resistant phone, than I don't see any real reason to own this particular device.

I used and tested both Exynos and SD820 : 
1. Exynos better in multitasking by far 
2. Less heat than SD820, almost nil. 
3. Battery lasts 1 to 2h more than SD820 
4. SD820 sometimes have lag, Exynos no. 
5. Graphic processing seems better on Exynos in my tests. 
6. SD820 better in single tasking but physically you don't feel it. 
7. By some reasons (i don't know why) Exynos was faster in networking/internet. 
So, my opinion is to take the Exynos, but is your decision.

To NASVIEWS:
 
I will openly say it, the Galaxy S5 is the best Galaxy S to date. I agree with everything you said. Its that time of the year when samsung take another shot at making a flagship smartphone.  
  Its nas views here with the review and opinion on the galaxy s7. 
  The galaxy line has always had its ups and downs each phone giving and taking aspects and features, trying to create something different from the rest. 
  The galaxy s7 in some ways is better then the s6 but is this upgrade really worth it? 4gb ram crazy fast chipset but a lower spec camera?  
  4gb ram sounds like your running a low spec laptop but in the smartphone world thats a whole lot of multitasking giving the user freedom to run as many apps as he wants without having to lose device performance, combined with the super fast chipset the galaxy s7 is a very capable phone. Is it necesary? No its not, most people will check their facebook write a few tweets watch some youtube videos maybe play a game in their spare time and even take some photos here and there thats about all really when it comes to usage so there isnt any need for 4gb of ram or the fastest chipset on the market. 
 
  The return of the sd card however is a great step forward as the galaxy s6 had a big sale loss due to the limited storage.  
  The water and dust resistance i guess is a big bonus considering samsung last had this feature on the galaxy s5 which till today i believe is the best galaxy on the market.
 
  The camera on the other hand has been downgraded to 12mp with the promise that it is much better in low light due to its pixels being bigger therefore capturing more light... but at what price losing detail in your images especially for someone who wants to print their photos and have them put up on the wall this could be an issue. So is the camera an upgrade? Yes and no. Better night shots but less detail in the day. Samsung i think if you want to create the perfect camera you should opt for a bigger sensor with a leica lens and keep the pixels where they where.  
  Over all the galaxy s7 personally apart from the sd card and the weather resistance i dont think there is much of an upgrade to be seen. Still a fingerprint magnet still slippery still has that buldge hanging out the back for the camera its really quite dissapointing to see the s7 with minimal upgrades
 
  Maybe next year samsung but for now the s5 will still be my daily driver  
 Nas views here peace out

May be the same if you follow the herd and upgrade your phone every year.  And in my opinion, that is complete non-sense.
 
But in my case, I upgraded from an S1 to the S4 and then the S4 to the S7.  Each upgrade had amazingly welcome new features and technology.
 
Quite thrilled with this new phone!

To P:
 
That's exactly what I'm talking about, the upgrades are basically the same as every other manufacturer upgrade for 2016 CPU, RAM, battery etc. 
 
The Galaxy S has been known for innovations which made it stood far out from the crowd. The S2 was a significant improvement over the first S. The S3 was just as significant over the S2 with things like smart alert, smart stay, pop-up player (have the video in a separate window while performing other tasks) etc. Then the S4 took things to a whole new level with features from the Samsung Smart TV and Galaxy Note 2 (Smart Scroll and Air View respectively) but the cool part about the Air View is that while the S-Pen was needed to do it on the Note 2 a pen wasn't needed to get it done on the S4...Samsung revamped the entire screen just for the Air View to work without a S-Pen...that's innovation.
 
Then along came the S5 with more innovations most notably the first smartphone to come with a heart rate sensor and the first Galaxy S to have a fingerprint sensor...that's innovation...and it's impressive to know that it is water resistant without it being the bulky active version...that too is innovation. Most impressively the S5 was able to maintain every feature from every previous Galaxy S (except the FM Radio which got cut since the S4). I only used the radio once on my S2 just to test it out so I won't cry about it being gone these days.
 
The S6 removed essential stuff like the SD slot and Ingress Protection and sealed the battery to top things off. That's not innovation. The S7 brings back the SD slot and Ingress Protection but removes the IR blaster  (infaRed) yet everybody jumps for joy. That's not innovation. Removing a feature from one model and bringing it back in another model is NOT innovation. 
 
Samsung has clearly ran out of ideas. I will stick to my S5 octa-core. It has everything including a removable battery which has sadly been gone since the S6. I guess I will have to wait to see what the S8 has to offer. Hopefully it will bring back true innovations to the table and not just offer a camera upgrade only in terms of pixels.

Hm, i guess it's expensive. I have a better alternative to S7. And that is Huawei P8 lite. It has top features, work perfectly, has a cheap price and opinions about it is the best. I really advise all of you who want a galaxy s7, to try a Huawei P8 lite.

To DARKMAN:
 
You aren't as dark as others probably think. You made a good point and you are correct, memory usually increase in increments by x2 (2,4,8,16,32 etc.). I guess that's being changed by Sandisk now. I don't think it's 256GB from Sandisk as 56GB is far too much to be used by the file system. A computer usually reads a 10GB hard disk drive as 9.x, a 20GB as 18.x, a 40GB as 38GB, a 60GB as 55GB and 80GB as 75GB. Even a 512GB hard disk drive doesn't lose as much as 56GB as a 512GB hard drive is read as 465GB. I understand your point but some of the other readers won't. Coming from the computer era it seems messed up. I'm using a desktop computer to compose this message (smile).

The phone is great and because the screen is so good its easy to neglect how bright it is, it will be easily readable about 12-15% brightness as long as you have reasonable eyesight unless your watching media or showing it off. There is also a setting in accessability-vision, for making the text more vivid , and it makes text jet , crisp black instead of grey. 
You probably know all these things anyway, but in case anyone doesn't, joyfully exploring the applications menues and settings menues by working your way through them, reveals lots of things you choose not to use and can disable or deny unneccesary permissions that have apps phoneing home about your location etc more times than  E T. Also the google plus thing  like farce book is a drainer so if you don't use either, get shut. 
Developer options turned on (anyone on here will tell how its done if need be.) , with animations set to either  0.5x or off and instead of standard turn background proccesses to 4, and with those tweeks, last evening we went to a gig, and with my normal daily use included + all the gig photos and 4k videos + intermintently video calling home to show em, I put the phone on airplane mode over night, took it off again this morning, played the video's check the photo's, read a book for 40 minutes ,been on gsma for 20 minutes and , at writing this my battery stats are ;
 
running time= 20 hours 4 minutes 
screen on    =   5 hours 2 minutes 
maps navigation 2% worth, few texts etc 
now mid morning at 19% usage.
 
This only on 6 edge plus, the which I have a bigger screen to run , so happy tweeking , you can get 8 plus hours of screen time depending on brightness, useage  and of course my sync settings are on demand so as the phone is not constantly polling for what is not even there.

How can you view having less megapixels as "going back"? Megapixels never have been what made a camera superior quality--sensor technology does, however impact QUALITY of photographs. The S7 is equipped with a dual pixel sensor, capturing up to 95% more light than the S6, providing a lower aperture, and faster focus time. This system provides a higher quality image than any increase in megapixels. You may increase the size of an image, however that doesn't mean that fidelity will increase. Please read up on camera sensors before bashing Samsung's choice. They're trying to give you more performance for your investment.

I believe you are referring to Samsung not allowing Adoptable Storage with SD cards on the Galaxy S7. You do realize that adopted cards are encrypted to be used with only the phone they are in, right? This would limit many unaware consumers to not having access to their data if they try to pull the card out and place it in another device (phone, computer, tablet, digital photo frame). 
 
Also, another potential issue with adoptable storage is the performance hit that some users may get when using a low read/write SD card; internal storage is MUCH faster. I doubt every consumer looking into this phone will know to seek out the best performing SD card to mitigate the performance hit. Typically, consumers will seek what fits their budget; if this means purchasing a $35 off-brand 128GB card vs a $60-80 high performance 64GB card, they will often save the money and choose what they feel is better bang for their buck. This is where I feel Samsung is simply standing off to watch and see how well things work out. We may see an update for the firmware that will change this situation. As of now, I think it's a smart choice, Android M is still new and not many end-users are aware of adoptable storage in the first place.

To BRYNN:
 
Brynn my old friend. You told the story well, though I overlooked the tv part. I have a HD TV and I totally forgot that at full HD photos are 2MP (give and take) as you put it. In fact it's a little less than some rated 2MP cameras because 2.4MP cameras have a resolution of 2048x1152 and they are still listed as just 2MP while a flat 2MP is resolution is 1600x1200...either way you take it though a 1080p HD TV have to be seen as a 2MP resolution.
 
I have always preached that if you aren't going to print a big poster or a billboard sized poster then 2MP is sufficient for most snaps. For my working purposes I snap photos at 2.4MP (that's the lowest resolution of my S5) and for other purposes I shoot photos at 6MP. Unless I go into the a real advertising business I will never have a need for anything more than 6MP (second resolution option on my S5 after 2MP) so even the 12MP of the S7 is a overkill just like the 16MP of the S5 was a overkill.
 
Many persons think that megapixels equals better photos but it's really the optics/lens that produce the quality...megapixels help in the large printing area and for zooming in purposes on a computer etc.
 
My S2 had 8MP and for the most part I didn't shoot photos at that resolution. Furthermore high-resolution photos fill up your memory very quickly whether internal or external and I won't even get started with HD video recording. 720p is enough for me. 1080p and UHD will make you spend money on memory cards faster than how you spend money on food.
 
Having said all that it's always better to have more features than less features because even though they may not be used for the most part, you can never tell when there will be that moment when you need to have the absolute best (like a rare one in a million moment).

Megapixel thought. 
 If anyone is viewing their pictures on a HD tv (1920x1080) then the MAXIMUM they are seeing is a 2 megapixel image. It does not matter what MP camera you use 5,8,10,12,23 or 41 you will only see a 2megapixel resolution image.
 
High res cameras are good for zooming in on but a 6 mp image printed out at 6x4 inches is pretty good.Unless you are printing poster size images most folk looking at pictures on their laptop are not seeing these high res images because it is impossible physics.
 
I would rather have a good quality image with excellent low light quality than a 100 mp camera.

A smartphone is most of all a computer, portable for that matter. I don't buy a smartphone 
for being a phone, there are so many superior alternatives for this job.(mainly the "dumbphones"...)

 
So it has to have the best battery life possible. Reducing battery size to make it thinner and cooler, is not wise, because it reduces portability. In general one expects to see an increase of battery life, still, for mobile devices. Because being mobile means less dependence from the wall socket. Thinness is never a substitute for this kind of independence. I hate myself for pointing out self-evident things, but it seems I must.
 
To make it clumsy accepting expandable storage , reduces portability , which is not wise. 
One SD slot is not enough already, absence of  even one is tragic.
 
To make it impossible to effectively communicate with the bulk of existing peripherals(such as big conventional monitors and screens as well as keyboards and mouses) reduces flexibility. 
I may want to enjoy my smartphone from the coziness of an office, on a nearby screen when available. How can anyone fail to understand that universal connectivity is essential for adopting new paradigms?
 
Rather adopting obscure communication protocols, allegedly in the name of progress, does not convince anyone.

Tho, SD card slots are great for expandable memory they have many faults aswell. 1. it can crash a phone just on its own, aswell can crash if not properly formatted which most people forget to do. 2. When using a external memory card it slows the phone down dramatically. 3. When you save files IE photos, music, videos or documents they can become corrupt, less dense (In short photos become blurry, music become distorted, document can actually be changed if saved because the phone may not have the same format that document  is in) or even you files can be lost. Another thing to consider is the design of the phone, now they dont have plan for a somewhat large slot it may not seem large to you but for a thin device it is.
 
With that in mind I am not saying an external memory card isnt worth it but it does cause issue that many of us deal with, again thats slow phone, the safety of our files and the overall shape, size and style of the device. Samsung will more than likely still ahve the same option to have a 100GB free online storage option, which in my eyes is much safer because it isnt stored on something I could lose or even break and not get back my info again. Now for other who need an external memory either to move files from or to your device they make a special reader for your phone to connect many different types of storage device medias and they are relatively cheap and im saying less than $10 on amazon.

Ignorance of the hard reboot routine is not the reason for my opposition to non removable batteries. The fact is that the battery is the most vulnerable and short-lived component in a phone, and for any manufacturer to link the life of a perfectly good phone to it's weakest component is stupidity beyond belief. Some of us have relatives in poor countries who would really appreciate our used phones - if only we could pop in a new battery before passing them on. Lastly, Royal Mail and an increasing number of couriers will only accept phones for carriage if the battery has been removed. I have a Galaxy Note 4 which is a year old with a battery that is dying. Fortunately I can still swap this one out, but after this, my next phone will be LG and not Samsung.

I was angry at first over the non-removable battery and SD card slot.  However, I decided to take the plunge and purchased a Note 5 with a 64GB memory.  I was very surprised by the battery performance.  I can be used heavily for the majority of the day and the battery holds up well.  It will charge from 10% to 100% in less than an hour and faster if it is turned off.  if you are on-the-go,  then I recommend an Anker 10,000mAh portable power bank.  They charge the phone quickly and you can charge it twice using the bank.   If you need to transfer files fast,  SanDisk makes a USB to micro USB transfer flash drive.  Mine is 32GB and it's easy to use.  You can also get a portable hard drive for smart phones.  Samsung has one out in 1.5TB but the reviews on it aren't great.  Other companies make them as well and they are slightly smaller than the phone.  They are nice if you travel a lot and want to watch a movie or access documents where wifi is weak, doesn't exist or isn't secure.  The point is that you don't need a memory card any more.   
 
I'm sure that the S7 will be even better and one rumor has the lens on the camera to have 1.2 aperture.  That's great for those fast shots.   With all of the options available to smart phones,  you won't need the extra battery or extra memory.

Removable battery seems to be a hot button issue. I can understand why they want to remove it, but it will change what device I purchase. I've had a Galaxy S4 for over two years and it is still going strong with crDroid and Android 6.0 with excellent battery life. Hoping to get three years out of the device before being back on the upgrade treadmill again.
 
For me, having a removable battery allows me to go on longer bike trips (twice a week, @ 80 km) and swap out the battery. Battery cases are clunky and don't fit into the bike mount, and external batteries are one more thing to tie down and worry about falling off down a hill at 60 km/h when you hit that bridge with bumps. It's a big plus to be able to swap it out at the end of a work day and have a completely full battery for the evening, regardless of what you plan on doing.
 
A lean phone is also nice as well, but not a compromise I can make.
